dairy products.description: Dairy products such as milk, cream, butter, and cheese were commonly consumed in 15th-century Europe. They were typically made by dairy farmers who owned cows, sheep, or goats that produced milk. The milk was then processed using various techniques such as churning, curdling, and pressing to produce the desired product. Buttermilk, a fermented drink made from sour milk, was also popular at the time.

These fibers would be spun into thread using a spinning wheel, then woven into cloth on a loom. The loom was typically made by carpenters or woodworkers and operated by weavers. It provides a comfortable and stable seating position for the weaver, allowing them to focus on their work without discomfort or distraction. Weaving stools are commonly used in conjunction with looms and other textile production tools, and are an essential part of the weaver's toolkit.

wrought iron.description: Wrought iron is a type of metal that is made by heating iron ore in a blast furnace until it becomes molten, then hammering it into shape while it is still hot and malleable. It was commonly used in 15th-century Europe for making tools, weapons, and other objects that required a strong and durable material.
